title: Young man with Down Syndrome has Tumoulin wood stall vandalised
text:
A young man with Down Syndrome has been left devastated after his roadside wood stall was vandalised by heartless thieves.

Jack Zieth, 20, from Tumoulin in Far North Queensland had his 'Jack's Hardwood & Woodcrafts' stall robbed three times earlier this month.

His family said the vandalism was a 'targeted attack' and revealed the stall's signs had been destroyed by the gutless criminals.

Jack, (pictured with wood stall), from Tumoulin in Northern Queensland had his 'Jack's Hardwood & Woodcrafts' stall robbed three times earlier this month

Jack's mother Nicki Zieth revealed the thieves had left behind less than a dollar for the wood as a cruel insult.

'The first day the crappy humans left 80cents total for 3 bags, yesterday 20cents for 3 bags,' Mrs Zieth she wrote on Facebook.

'Jack just doesn't understand why someone would be taking his wood and frankly neither do we.'

'It's only something small but it's something huge to someone who has special needs,' Jack's father Tony told 7 News.

'They take it personally and young Jack wears his emotions on his sleeve.'

Jack (pictured) and his family had set up the business last year and his father Tony said running the stall was his biggest passion and checks the wood daily

After hearing Jack's story, Aaron Hagbood, the chef at five-star hotel Shangri-La Cairns, offered to donate 200kg of wood.

'I saw the unfortunate things that happened so I thought well why not help him with a 200kg order,' Mr Hagbood said.

A Facebook page was set up for Jack's business in the wake of the robbery and has been flooded with requests for people wanting to buy wood.

Jack and his family have been flooded with requests for wood after sharing the news of the robberies online
